title: Will Keiko Fujimori win Peru's upcoming presidential election?
preds: Count over 99.9% done and 42k vote difference remaining. That's all, folks!
Kuczynskiâ€™s lead is greater than total uncounted votes, per perureports.com
I was badly wrong on this one, had predicted 75% then upgraded to 90% then 95%, all in response to polls.

With about 360k, or less as Gibson pointed out, disputed ballots sent to a "special electoral board" I think this is a blow for Kuczynski. This election has been described as  "semi-democractic" by media analysts. The electoral boards have shown several times to rule hard against her opponents but go easy on her. 
I get the impression too that the atmosphere in Peru is tense, and both candidates are taking pains to stay silent or promote "calm And tranquility". This makes me think Peruvians expect her votes to prevail. Ppk had a surprisingly strong showing for an underdog so I think the  outcome whatever it is might leave a lot of people unhappy.
Very few votes left to count, though some may be reviewed. She's behind by a very small margin, but she can only hope and pray now. Very unlikely.

not changing forecast b/c it doesn't matter now (see summary-to-forecast field UPDATE).
Rick's link to live coverage: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/253596 (putting it on the front page)
lol wish i'd known this: see update to Summary of forecasting problem today.
I guess this will take a few more days. Every vote counts.
If you want to check how it is going live, https://resultadoselecciones2016.onpe.gob.pe/PRP2V2016/Resumen-GeneralPresidencial.html#posicion
Looks like Kuczynski has eked it out. Don't know how long it will take to sort out all the disputed ballots, though. And expatriate votes (4% of potential votes) have not been counted yet.
I think Mr. Kuczynski has pulled off an amazing come from behind win.
With over 90% of the votes counted so far, Fujimori is still slightly behind.

18.7m votes cast. http://www.idea.int/vt/countryview.cfm?CountryCode=PE.  Assume none spoiled (conservative as typically not less than 10pc * normally* 20pc).  5.8 pc left to count with 90000 to turnover ( https://www.google.ca/amp/s/amp.ft.com/content/8165e4a6-2ba7-11e6-a18d-a96ab29e3c95?client=ms-android-rogers-ca#) means min remaining 54 to 46 to fujimori to win  but more likely higher on spoiled votes.  
Oh,  and I've been low on fujimori for so long I am twisting the numbers to suit me.

Standing by early assessment: 
- Keiko hasn't distanced herself from Dad's death squad legacy
- can't control brother who supports dad, i think
- doesn't have worker vote
- narrowly won first round, narrowly losing second round
- seems to be calculated in political affairs, (like getting private secretary resignation) when I think the people want her to show them kinder traits.
Before looking into the details any more, it seems like the expectations took a turn for the worse in the past days.

Raising a bit.
With 88,02% he led by 50,52% against 49,48%.
With 91,01% the lead reduced to 50,32% against 49,68%
With 9% of the votes to be counted, keeping that rate she would be elected with 50,3% of the votes
90% of votes counted and only 164,000 separating them.

Reducing from 60% to 55%.
Keeping her chances above 50%.
She may reverse his lead once votes from the countryside and Peruvians living abroad are counted. She has strong support among them.
https://resultadoselecciones2016.onpe.gob.pe/PRP2V2016/Resumen-GeneralPresidencial.html#posicion
Kuczynski had 50.59 percent of the vote against 49.41 percent for Fujimori, with 52 percent of votes counted.

Keiko only has 7% chance according to PredictIT and latest polling shows her behind. 
https://www.predictit.org/Market/2177/Who-will-win-the-Peruvian-presidential-runoff-election
Down from 85 to reflect the last opinion polls, exit polls and early results, This is going to be close!
Official ONPE count up to 51.7%: PPK 50.59%, Keiko 49.41%
Polls show Fujimori is running slightly behind!

The forecast today is unlikely to matter but anyway: Between exit polls, unofficial counts and preliminary official results, the chance of reversal is really small. Damn, this turned out to be very close and it all turned around in the last 3-4 days max!

2 of 3 exit polls show Fujimori losing.
http://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-36454328
It looks as though the scandals are having an effect & It's closer than I expected.

Quick count up to 77% by GfK --> PPK 51.5 - Keiko 48.5
Quick count up to 84% by Ipsos --> PPK 50.9 - Keiko 49.1
The election day is over.  According to "a boca de urna" (they interview people after voting) , the result is slightly in favour of PPK, but it is still impossible to guarantee a winner.

With just 2 days left, I can't get to the true probability of 50% even if I drop all the way down to 0%. 
Might as well take that option since it is the one that makes the maximum difference.

Well, this appears to be a 50-50 election, but consensus is above 80% with just couple of days left. And since I mistakenly thought it was a safe bet, I entered at 90% about a week back. What to do now? Go to consensus or go to true probability? I can't decide. I am positioning to get in the middle of the two, with a slight bias towards consensus.
According to Reuters, Ipsos poll gives PPK has a small lead over Keiko.

Going way down based on apparent last day reversal in the polls, courtesy of @RickPrieto:
http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/251312
http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/251342
And IPSOS poll today confirmed the trend: PPK 50.4; Keiko 49.6. It will be a close decision, nevertheless.

Dropping based on reports of Keiko's lead narrowing. I think the last couple of days may show a momentum shift which I believe typically influences all of those undecideds. Which isn't good news for Keiko... perhaps that the protests have had an effect.
Thanks to @Dima-K for the link:
http://perureports.com/2016/06/04/fujimori-kuczynski-seen-tied-one-day-perus-election/

The leaked polls have confirmed the trend we have seen during this week: PPK is already ahead (2.2% advantage, 1.6% margin of error) according to GfK. Later today I will also post Ipsos poll, which should reaffirm PPK's advantage.
El Pais newspaper is calling the race at a statistical tie and says Keiko's lead is narrowing.  A significant public demonstrations that have drawn thousands may be having an effect.

The latest leaked Datum and GfK polls show that the gap between Keiko and PPK has narrowed. 
Datum shows that the valid vote gap went from 5.8% to 4.2%, whereas GfK shows that it went from 4.4% to 0.6%.
The GfK is the latest one, and includes polling from 1st and 2nd of June, after Veronika Mendoza and other political leaders showed public support to PPK. This shows a clear upward trend for PPK, which will lead to a closer result on Sunday than people here expect.
Recent opinion polls indicate that Fujimori may be gaining popularity.

Revising up in view of newest poll, which has Fujimori ahead again, this time by an even wider margin. FIrst debate happened last week and apparently there was a perception that she won. Source is Ipsos [1]. (Link in Spanish.)

The last poll by CPI (not published in the media due to legal restrictions) shows that the gap between Keiko and PPK has narrowed from 9.6% (poll published last Sunday) to 3.2%, in a poll made during the last two days. According to CPI, this poll measures the effect of:

She has a good chance of winning, she is currently in the lead but their aren't many articles that describe the negative view of her. The bias makes it hard to judge, I found statistics mostly favoring her.
raising slightly again due to the rising consensus and the low turnout in protests mentioned by @victorsp33.

Raising her odds, remaining below consensus.
Low turnout (5 thousand people) in protest against Keiko.
The day of judgement is coming up, and she has an unbeatable lead. Polls are most accurate in the last week or days before the election.

Keiko is leading the polls by as much 5 points. The most recent Ipsos poll released on Sunday (which has been very accurate on the week prior to the elections on the first round and on the presidential election in 2011) shows:
Latest poll indicates Keiko is trending to take it all. Link here http://en.mercopress.com/2016/05/31/keiko-fujimori-seems-set-to-become-peru-s-next-president-on-june-5-
coming down 20 percentage points due to @RickPrieto, thanks again!

In last Sunday's presidential debate, PPK was the clear winner. He focused on highlighting his experience and legacy as Finance Minister and Prime Minister, as well as the party that represents democracy. In contrast to the previous debate, he answered every dirty attack and lie that Keiko threw at him, while also making a link between drug trafficking, corruption (activities that were linked to Alberto Fujimori's government and that in recent weeks have been strongly associated with the current Fujimori party) and crime, which has become the main concern of people in Lima. He criticised Keiko for missing 500 days of work as a Congresswoman (she answered that she went on maternity leave twice, but that only covers 180 days), asked if she was going to extradit her uncles from Japan, who have ongoing corruption charges in Peru (she said that she was not going to interfere with justice), and wondered why the police had found over 100kg of cocaine in a warehouse owned by Kenji, Keiko's brother (she said that it was normal that drug trafficking infiltrate local businesses!?!?!?!?). He ended the debate on a high note. In Piura, Keiko told him "How have you changed, pelona" (in reference to a known poem), because he supported her last elections. In the last debate, PPK answered: "You haven't changed a little bit, pelona, you are still the same", in reference to her father's legacy and her role as first lady in his government.
The last several polls have shown her with about  5% lead.

Support for illegal miners may have been the key.
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-peru-election-mining-idUSKCN0YM1R1
Polls confirm her ahead of the opponent. Still want to be below consensus.

raising my forecast due to the polls; stayed below 50% for the whole time.
Fujimori is winning outside MOE as of a poll released yesterday. [http://www.ipsos.pe/sites/default/files/opinion_data/Opinion%20Data%20Mayo%20IV%202016.pdf]

As @Khalid noted, the three latest polls (by three different pollsters) all give KF a win outside of the margin of error. Margin of error commonly cited is 95% CI. Might as well take it literally. Polling in Peru, in general and during this electoral cycle, has been pretty much spot on at all times.

The latest Ipsos poll shows 43% of Peru’s voters support Fujimori, compared to 38% for Kuczynski. Fujimori’s five-point lead reflects political momentum in her favor since the same poll one week ago gave her a three-point advantage.

Seems her campaign effort is focused on voter groups that may make a difference.
also sad to say but being a woman in a relatively patriarchal nation works against her

I think she is going to lose this to Kuzcynski.
- can't distance herself from her families authoritarian record
- money laundering moved from 'allegation' to an open investigation
- Mario Vargas Llosa roundly supports Kuzcynski. I think he is one of the few non-politicians with untold amounts of influence on popular opinion
- has not been able to move voters in polls to widen her gap. I think the longer candidates stay neck and neck, the more likely the front-runner is to lose
-adjusting to account for Kuzcynski's poor showing in debate and fact that polls grow more accurate closer to election and still don't show Keiko a majority ahead

In the past few weeks I think we have learned some important lessons about forecasting elections.

A joint report between Univisión and Cuarto Poder (Peruvian news programme) has confirmed that the DEA is currently investigating Joaquin Ramírez, Fuerza Popular's Secretary (basically Keiko's right hand), for an audio in which Ramírez says he laundered $15 million for Keiko's campaign in 2011. It is currently being exploited by the media in Peru, so it will have a major impact in the next few weeks. This time, Keiko cannot victimise herself because the DEA is an independent agency.

Illegal mining in Peru is actually "big business".  If PKK continues to make macro arguments and Fujimori continues to support micro causes, her lead may continue to increase. Presidential candidate of Peruvians for Change, Pedro Pablo Kuczynski (PPK), has a vote intention of 50.1%, while Popular Strength presidential candidate, Keiko Fujimori garnered 49.9% of the votes ahead of the 5 June runoff, according to the latest GFK survey, released this week.

While Fujimori’s legacy is controversial – some credit the former dictator with ending longstanding conflicts between the government and rebel groups in Peru, despite known human rights abuses – analysts agree that the exclusion of both Guzmán and Acuña favours Keiko’s candidacy.
Historically voter go for the least "scary" candidate. Not in her favour.

The latest poll has Keiko Fujimori taking 39.9% of the vote which is almost 18% more than her nearest challenger Pedro Kuczynski. Elections aren't held for another month so I am keeping my forecast as is for the time being.
It looks like it's still too close to call http://www.peruthisweek.com/news-ppk-keiko-fujimori-tie-109434

electoral authority in a semi-democratic election, stock market up
2nd place candidate losing momentum, to me this means more of the undecided votes have moved support to front-runner or other candidates. Gap between first and second should widen going forward.

Protests against father represent about  2.5% of population maybe double this

A second low fi-poll was just released (you can google it in the name of "free discovery) that has Keiko winning by around a 52-48 margin, making the entire poll taking excercise a wash.  The arrest in Brazil of the FARC's top "drug czar" responsible for the cocaine corridor and shipments on the Peru-Colombia-Brazil- West Africa corridor could cause a few shoes to drop, and among some global players, raise issues of who can control narco-dollas better, the pedo viejo PPK and his Janqui puppetmasters, or Keiko's people, who still have links to the old Vlad Montesinos network.

Polls show statistical deadheat. Some show Keiko leading by 2%, others give Kuczynski the edge.  At this point, one would have to see which campaign has the most funds to spend (buying votes, suppressing voters, the usual).  There is a high number of undecided voters still. We also have to look at what the smaller parties will do in terms of declaring alliances and giving public support to a candidate.
NEW POLL result show the Fujimori with a slight lead - It is within the margin of error.

Hopefully I'm allowed to revise my forecast as I'm not sure here; it's a topic I'm following with interest though as a 'bellwether' for changes in Latin American politics...many relevant factors related to support/political changes in other Latin American countries, association with Alberto Fujimori (thus far seems weak signals and uptake abroad, less so among her actual supporters in Peru, although don't underestimate Latin American distaste for 'strongmen' leaders having an effect there and in terms of other countries' attitudes to this contest). In short I think she seems to be on track although am quite willing to be proven wrong.

First poll Focused on the run off gives Kuczynski the lead:
http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2016/04/18/asia-pacific/kuczynski-leads-fujimori-ahead-of-peru-runoff-election-opinion-poll-shows/#.VxUY6oE8KrV
The Panama Papers leak may hurt her chances a little.

The results reported earlier in the press weren't right, the latest from the official ONPE site are: KF 39.84%, PPK 21.00% and Mendoza 18.82%.  With these results, PPK has to gain 19% of the vote, basically double his vote, too much of an uphill battle.  On the other hand, Mendoza said: "between the two options,KF is the worst".  So I move my percentage only 5% up.

KF with 40% and PK with 24% that gives a 16% difference.  Voting in compulsory, so everybody has to cast a vote.  Mendoza's followers will have serious problems supporting PK being so close to Wall street (and not even speaking good Spanish).  He is also too old for the job, the young generation will be inclined to vote KF. I read several of Peru's newspapers and it is very strange the low level of discussion about the runoff election.  All in all, I think KF will take it.  I would vote 100% if it weren't for the Brier index which makes no gains close to mark but big penalties far from it. (This is a separate pet peeve that I have, it makes no practical sense in a binary decision to go above 80%).
Her runoff is now against Kuczynski (K) (http://www.reuters.com/article/us-peru-election-idUSKCN0X708N) after the candidates won 39.5% and 21.6% of the vote, respectively.
First, I googled who won Peru's past elections. Recent history:

Great link from @anneinak with good info from:
http://www.arabnews.com/world/news/909471
I've been skeptical of Keiko all along, but her chances of winning got much higher. Still think she will lose.
No changes reported in the news.
It seems like it's going to be pretty close. Better campaign organization probably outweights the negatives of being her father's daughter.
I am still parsing where the support for the also rans will land post Panama Papers.
going higher until we get some opinion polls

This is a tough one.  Both Kuzcynski and Fujimori are often referred to as “right-wing,” but Kuzcynski is generally somewhat more centrist than Fujimori and is not hampered by her family baggage. Her dad was and is very popular with about 20% of Peruvians and she pulled almost twice that in the first round.  On the other hand, it is not out of the question that 40% is close to her max since supporters of the also-rans are believed to be a bit more likely to support PPK or stay home than switch to her.  Polls should start coming in soon; stay tuned.
bumping up a bit. Think KF now a slight second-round favourite,; partly appeal to poor voters, partly Shining Path

I believe her opponent, an economist who has held several high profile government is going to win the election with the votes of the middle and upper class.   Fujimori has too many negatives - just like most of the U.S. candidates - and is unlikely to pick up many votes of the rest of the candidates who missed the run off cutoff.

Looking at the polls, Keiko looks to be the "Donald Trump" of Peru.  Which is to say, she has a solid base of support.  But she is so polarizing, she is going to have a very hard time expanding on that.  In contrast, her opponent in the run-off has no such baggage, and has broader appeal.

Adjusting my forecast because of the results of the election and pre-election polls showing Fujimori would lose to Kuczynski in a 2nd round.  Lowering it to make up for 2 days during which forecasting on this question was blocked.

Fujimori is still the most likely winner - all the polling before the first round showed her with a double digit lead against any other candidate. But her victory is much less likely against Kuczynski than it would have been against Mendoza, as he is a candidate that it will be easier for anti-Fujimori voters to rally around. I think this will be harder to call than many people thought a few weeks ago.

Keiko will face Kuczynski in June runoff...polls show he has 7% lead in runoff (polls conducted before today's election).

Moving up from 72% to my initially over optimistic forecast of 88% probability. Simply put, she has a much shorter hill to climb than either of the two other candidates she might face in the upcoming run-off election. The two other candiates, Mendoza and Kuczynski have enough of a divergence in their bases that it would likely be difficult to mount an effective combination of forces to counter Fujimori. Much more likely that the Kuczynski centrists will find much more common ground with the Fuerza Popular.
"Centre-right candidate Keiko Fujimori has won the first round of Peru's presidential election, exit polls say.

But will all this be enough for Ms Fujimori to win the presidency? She is in a much stronger position than five years ago. Her rival, Ms Mendoza, shows no desire to make the move from left to centre that brought Mr Humala victory, although she says she would not copy chavista Venezuela. Should Mr Kuczynski make it onto the June ballot, he would have a better chance of uniting the anti-Fujimori vote.

Adjusting this way up because the election is tomorrow and I'm not going to be home for the deadline to this question. If there is a runoff, I'll adjust back down.

Latest polls:  
Keiko leads with 37% vs a statistical deadheat between Kuczynski 20.3% and Mendoza un 20.1% who are fighting for a spot on a round off election in June.

The protests grab headlines, but the polls grab my attention. Even if a lot of people hate Keiko, a lot more people seem to like her. And the Panama Papers stuff seems to touch most of the other candidates as well -- I don't know why it would disadvantage her especially.

In my opinion, there are a couple of factors in play that point in different directions:
1) Economic disparity, Peru seemed on the verge of economic success in 2010/2011, but that has failed to materialize.  Couple that with an increase in economic disparity between rural and less affluent citizen vs urban / affluent citizens and everything points left.  This would make sense, but a) Peru, especially rural and young Peru, leans toward big changes and are distrustful of the political system http://www.vanderbilt.edu/lapop/peru/2010-political-culture.pdf + the current leftist leader is very unpopular and distrusted.  This suggests that even though voters  may support leftist ideologies, they would not expect the leftist candidate Mendoza (who is of the same party as the current president) to be the answer.  She is sitting around 15-20% in most polls and that seems about right.
I'm skeptical that Keiko will win, and the 75% odds are very unlikely. Given the extent of protests against her, and the fact that the poling is tied, 50% is the highest possible number.

Still certain she makes the runoff election, but now her runoff opponent looks equally likely between Kuczynski and Mendoza, though Mendoza has momentum in the polls (http://www.ipsos.pe/sites/default/files/opinion_data/OpinionData030416.pdf).

Returning to 45%. I'd intended to stay at 85 till the first round results were known, on the slight chance she might get 50%. However, latest polls as pointed out by @Salvador_Allende, the large street demonstrations against her and revelations in the Panama Papers http://www.telesurtv.net/english/news/Panama-Papers-Reveal-Keiko-Fujimori-Funded-by-Dirty-Money-20160404-0037.html suggest the contest will go to a run-off when opposition to her will consolidate.

This is certainly not a boring election!  
After campaigning began, 2 top candidates were disqualified for "vote buying" 
There have been huge protest rallies against the leading candidate (Fujimori) who was also charged, but cleared, of vote buying.
The #2 candidate (Kuczynski) has been charged with vote buying and may be barred from the race.
An archbishop said it would be a sin to vote for the #3 or #4 candidates, 
While a bishop emeritus said he could never vote for the #1 candidate.
Polls say the leading candidate may not win in a run-off.
The highest vote-getter in the polls is "Undecided".
Will the Undecideds vote for Fujimori because of name recognition (her father had been president)?  
or will the Undecideds vote for "Anyone but Fujimori"?

3/21 The electoral board has three days to decide the fate of Keiko Fujimori; they will vote on whether or not to exclude her from the presidential elections this year.
Keiko Fujimori has been accused of allegedly having given money to voters in a cultural activity in Callao on Feb. 14. — there are photos and videos of circumstances in which she distributes money
The electoral authorities believe enough evidence exists to open a case to exclude Keiko Fujimori for presumed non-compliance with Article 42 of the Organic Elections Law that bans any payment of money or gifts.
i.e. Acuña, a businessman, was disqualified because his campaign had distributed money to voters, while economist and former Cabinet minister Guzman - who was running second in the polls - was ousted over supposed irregularities in how his party chose its presidential ticket.
